content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud. Section 1341 and 1343 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to increase the maximum penalty from five to twenty years. Additionally, a new section 1348 is added to address securities fraud with penalties of fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both for those involved in fraudulent schemes related to securities. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud under section 12 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 or section 6 of the Securities Act of 1933. Offenders can face fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933. Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include tampering with records or impeding official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. Additionally, there is an amendment to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud and related offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, consider new guidelines for enhancing penalties for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is also asked to ensure that guidelines reflect the seriousness of securities and pension fraud. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, ensuring they reflect the seriousness of such offenses and consider penalties for corporate officers committing fraud. This includes accounting for aggravating or mitigating circumstances and ensuring adequate offense levels for obstruction of justice and fraud cases. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review and update sentencing guidelines for fraud offenses with over 50 victims, make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, and ensure they align with the purposes of sentencing. The Commission must act promptly, within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, to implement these guidelines or amendments. "Debts incurred in violation of securities fraud laws are nondischargeable." Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as nondischargeable debts. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes provisions for nondischargeable debts related to claims from judgments, settlements, or court orders for damages, penalties, or payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Failure to comply with this certification can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties for violating financial report certification requirements. Violators may face fines exceeding $1,000,000 or imprisonment up to 10 years, or fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years for willful violations. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempting or conspiring to commit offenses against the United States, with the same penalties as the actual offense. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, raising fines to $5,000,000 and imprisonment to 20 years. SEC. 9 introduces temporary freeze authority for the Securities and Exchange Commission. SEC. 9 introduces temporary freeze authority for the Securities and Exchange Commission, allowing the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow extraordinary payments for 45 days during an investigation involving possible violations of the Federal securities laws. The Securities and Exchange Commission can petition a Federal district court for a temporary order to escrow payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days during an investigation. The temporary order becomes effective immediately and remains in place unless modified by a court of competent jurisdiction. The Securities and Exchange Commission can request a temporary order from a Federal district court to freeze payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days during an investigation. The order can be extended for an additional 45 days if necessary, but not exceeding a total of 90 days. If any violations of the Federal securities laws are charged before the order expires, the issuer or relevant party will face consequences. If violations of Federal securities laws are charged before the temporary order expires, it remains in effect until legal proceedings conclude, with the right to petition for review. If no violations are charged, the escrow terminates at the order's expiration. The temporary order under subparagraph (A) expires after 45 days, and the escrow terminates with disputed payments returned to the issuer. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Commission has the authority to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 grant the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 empower the Commission to bar individuals who have breached regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers. The amendment to section 1933 (15 U.S.C. 77h-1) allows the Commission to issue orders prohibiting individuals who have violated section 17(a)(1) or related rules from serving as officers or directors of issuers with registered securities. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information on Federal offenses to law enforcement. Penalties include fines or up to 10 years imprisonment.
